texts.definition: Storytelling that occurs through movement and exploration of an environment.
markups: <style="Definition">Storytelling that occurs through movement and exploration of an environment.</style>

Many games tell stories as part of playing them. While this can be done through cutscenes and dialogues and thereby guarantee how the narration is done, an alternative is to use <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style>. While focusing more on previous events than future events, this makes the unfolding take place as part of actual gameplay due to players noticing things about the game world, and lets players have a freedom to try and figure out what had happened or not.
For more on Environmental Storytelling, see articles on Gamasutra, presentations at Game Developers' Conference, and Game Design as Narrative Architecture by Jenkins.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Bioshock%20series">Bioshock series</link></style>, as well as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%203">Fallout 3</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout:%20New%20Vegas">Fallout: New Vegas</link></style> all provide places where things and effects on the environment give hints of what has happened earlier. In many cases there are related things and effects in other places of the game world, and players that find these can piece together possible narratives.

Hideouts of the resistance in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Half-Life%202">Half-Life 2</link></style> are often marked by a lambda symbol. While this shows that other people in the game world are struggling for the same cause as the player and have set up camps while doing so, it also gives hints the resources may be available. Evidence of other survivors are similarly present in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Portal%202">Portal 2</link></style>.

Player of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Doom%203">Doom 3</link></style> can find PDAs that have belonged to various people on Mars. They both give insights into the everyday life and provide hints on how to access resources later in the game.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

While deciding on what story that should be told by <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> is not in the scope of gameplay design, the specific design elements are since they are also those that help create <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style>. The latter of these can be virtue of not describing unnecessary parts make the <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> hard to miss.

The typical set of game elements available include <style="Link"><link="big-dumb-objects">Big Dumb Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> can also be used, especially those that can contain information, e.g. notes, books, and computers. While <style="Link"><link="landmarks">Landmarks</link></style> are <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, they can usually not provide enough information to carry <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style>. They can however modulate them by pointing players to other parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and make it easy to backtrack to earlier parts of them. <style="Link"><link="scripted-information-sequences">Scripted Information Sequences</link></style> is the most active form of <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> since it may involve the actions of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> but it is still a form of <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> since it is located within <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> during gameplay and players may have a <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to engage in the unfolding events or not.

As an incentive to make players interested in the various pieces of <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> available in a game, the game elements used to tell them may be placed in <style="Link"><link="resource-locations">Resource Locations</link></style>.

When using <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> to provide <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> in games, it may be worth considering to combine this with other ways, e.g. <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style> or through <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style>.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>
<style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> is both a diegetic and narrative pattern.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

As said above, <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> is both a diegetic and narrative pattern. Besides providing <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> integrated into <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> can also provide <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style> to the players.

When <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> is intended to be experienced in several different chunks, the use of <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> that successively are opened up can ensure that they are encountered in the right order. It is probably more fitting to make use of the pattern, or at least use it more often, in <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style> than in other types of locations since players can focus on them there and these routes can otherwise be uninteresting areas.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

<style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> is a way for games to have <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style> integrated into <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, and thereby have the <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> of the game embedded in the game environment. Players have the <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> to engage in these <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> or not, but may have to do <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style> in order to figure out, or at least guess, what actually transpired. In this way, they represent <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style> for players.

While <style="CurrentLink">Environmental Storytelling</style> can be used purely to provide <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style> or help players locate <style="Link"><link="resource-locations">Resource Locations</link></style>, they can also used to create <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>.

<style="H3">Can Instantiate</style>

<style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="predetermined-story-structures">Predetermined Story Structures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="optional-goals">Optional Goals</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="traces">Traces</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="resource-locations">Resource Locations</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="big-dumb-objects">Big Dumb Objects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="environmental-effects">Environmental Effects</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="scripted-information-sequences">Scripted Information Sequences</link></style>
